lines.text: You realize who goes to see movies. Eighty percent of them are between the ages of 12 and 22. And you know what the kids like?
What?
defy authority, destroy property, and take people's clothes off.

[bollixed]
What does that have to do with American history?

Oh, come on, Michael, think about it for a second. Why do kids defy authority? Because they're in rebellion. The American revolution, Michael, was the ultimate rebellion. *And* they destroyed property! So all we had to do with these lunatics' help was to get their clothes off.

[Meeting the director for the first time]
Yeah, the script is, uh... very interesting. There are only a couple of things I have a problem with.

[unconcerned]
Oh, yeah? What are they?
The story, and the dialogue.
Wonderful welcome. Maniacs in tights - Shooting.
[Stanley is trying to check into his hotel]
I have to get right to my suite. I'm the writer.
So? I'm the stunt coordinator.
So you can fall down later - I have writing that can't wait.
[On Stanley's adaptation of Michael's book]
You're not upset are you?

[annoyed]
I think I should warn you - I have a sword in my bag.

[to Michael]
How can you teach History and have such a short memory?
Hi Mom. I brought you your groceries
Put them on the TV.
Mom, why do you always put your groceries on the TV?
I always put them there and keep them there for a week. The radiation kills the poison that they put in them.
Mom, there's no poison in your groceries. Why don't you put them in the kitchen?
You know why.
[whispers]
Because "he's" in there.
Who, Mom? The Devil?
[Cecelia nods]
Mom, the Devil is not in your kitchen.

[of the screenplay's historical inaccuracies]
Tarleton was a vicious ruthless beast! Why would she fall in love with this guy?
He's number four at the box office.
What?
Elliott James is an international star. He comes on the screen in Paris, they wet their pants in Manila. If she *doesn't* fall in love with him, the audience will set fire to the *ushers*.

[on meeting the lead actress out of period costume]
I'm trying to get used to how *different* you look. You--you know, you're two different people!
Oh, well, if all I could be is two different people, I'd be out of business!

[of his philandering]
You know what my problem is? The way they smell. The perfume of their skin. It's, it's so intoxicating. I told my wife I'd never even *look* at other women if only I could cut off my nose.
What'd she say?
She said I was aiming too high.

[on seeing Michael nearly pick a fight with her co-star Elliott out of jealousy]
I think if you have a complaint, you ought to take it up with me.
Exactly how far do you take being Mary Slocum?
How far do you take being an historian?
I would stop short of sleeping with George the Third. *Why* would you have anything to do with him?
Because he's a witty, charming man, and because it helps our scenes.
Helps your *scenes*?
When I look in his eyes now, there's someone there. Do you--do you know what it feels like to act with someone who has the emotional depth of an eggplant?

[truly astonished]
You're not at *all* like her!

[quietly, also astonished]
Where have you been the last ten weeks?

[Stanley calls Michael and himself "The Two Musketeers"]
I'm not a musketeer, I'm a historian!

[to Stanley, who wants to inject more comedy into the screenplay]
The American Revolution was NOT a goddamned vaudeville show!
I'll tell you what, Mrs. Burgess, why don't I make you some lunch?
Sure! Some poisoned food would just finish me off!
Well, they were all out of poisoned food today. We got the other kind.
I don't eat anything that hasn't been sitting on the TV for 24 hours. The radiation kills whatever poison they put in there.
Remind me not to talk to Faith when she's in her street clothes.
